title: How does Aristotle explain the mean as it relates to humans? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q. How does Aristotle explain the mean as it relates to humans?  (1) This is one of those things that Aristotle got famous for, without his expecting it. If Ari is with us now, he’ll tell us that there’s no such thing as the ‘Doctrine of the Golden Mean’. There is something we might call a ‘doctrine of the mean’. But, there’s nothing very golden about it. (2) The doctrine says that every moral virtue lies at a midpoint between opposed vices. What does this mean? It isn’t a geometrical midpoint.It isn’t a point of moderation either.(3) The doctrine amounts to this. Simply, in order to be virtuous, don’t do or feel either too much, or too little. Like when the doctor advised you to take ‘the appropriate amount’ of medicine. Not too much. Not too little. But, this is not terribly helpful. How much medicine is appropriate for you, here and now, andwhat is the right thing to do or feel.There’re some rules of thumb. Don’t drink yourself stupid every evening. Be generous to your friends when they need you. Don’t run away at the first sight of your enemy. And so on. Apart from these, you’ve to use your moral sensibility. A philosopher can’t do anything for you. Then, what’s the use of Ethics philosophers, and the Philosophy of Ethics? (4) The question before us is: How do we make a success of our lives? How’re we to flourish, and to be happy? Answer: To be a good human being. To be a finished product of the human species. It’s a matter of having, and consistently acting upon, the virtues. It follows that for you to flourish, you need to live in accordance with characteristically human virtues. (5) Types of Virtues (5a) There’re the virtues of character, aka moral virtues. Courage, generosity, justice, friendliness, wittiness. (5b) There’re the virtues of intellect. Knowledge, wisdom, acuity. These’re superior to the virtues of character. The life of scientific and philosophical study is the highest form of human life. But, not everyone is capable of highfalutin soaring virtues of intellect. That’s fine. Make the best of virtues of character. Especially if you’re in politics. (6) Are virtues merely inclinations then? Yes, and so too, vices. But, they’re not just inclinations to act. Doctrine of the Mean talks about doing and feeling. Virtues (and vices) are inclinations to feel, as well as to act. (7) To be virtuous, must we master our emotions? No. (7a) For example, fear. It’s the emotion involved with courage. We often say: ‘Brave men are fearless’. Taken literally, that’s false. A soldier who isn’t afraid of a bayonet through his groin isn’t brave. He’s insensible. There’s no virtue in that. You shouldn't try to eliminate your fears. There’re plenty of things it’s rational to be afraid of. You shouldn’t try to master your fears. A brave man isn’t someone who trembles inside, but manages to bottle it up, and get on with the job. That’s self-control. It’s better than nothing. But, it’s not virtue. A brave soldier is often very afraid. He doesn’t have to master his fear. He acts with his fear, not in spite of it. (8) For example, love. You’ll agree it’s insane to suppress all feelings of love. But equally, it’s not good to master your love, if you’ve to force yourself to act in the appropriate loving way when you really don't feel much love. Or, when you’re overwhelmed with passion. A good lover has the right amount of love for his children, for his friends. And ‘right’ isn’t the same as ‘moderate’. What would you think of a Mom who has a moderate love for her kids?  Above: Nicomachean Ethics, Aristotle's best-known work on ethics. The work, which plays a pre-eminent role in defining Aristotelian ethics, consists of 10 books, originally separate scrolls, and is understood to be based on notes from his lectures at the Lyceum. Nicomachus is his son.
